  60 year old man with food impaction in esophagus, taken to OR for rigid
  endoscopy/removal.

  Evaluate for pneumomediastinum
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 CHEST PORTABLE AP.

 REASON FOR EXAM:  Evaluate for pneumomediastinum.

 FINDINGS:

 No pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum.  A focal new opacity in the right lung
 base could be due to recent aspiration or developing pneumonia.  The remaining
 lungs are clear, heart size and mediastinal contours are normal.

 IMPRESSION:

 Subtle opacity in the right lower lung could be due to recent infection or
 aspiration.  A early follow up CXR is recommended.
data.doc_2:
Sinus rhythm. Left ventricular hypertrophy with ST-T wave abnormalities. ECG shows low voltage and electrical alternans consistent with pneumomediastinum. The
ST-T wave changes with prolonged QTc interval are diffuse and may be due to
left ventricular hypertrophy but cannot exclude myocardial ischemia. Clinical
correlation is suggested. No previous tracing available for comparison.

value.text: No pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum.
Sinus rhythm. Left ventricular hypertrophy with ST-T wave abnormalities. ECG shows low voltage and electrical alternans consistent with pneumomediastinum.

data.doc_2:
[**Age over 90 **] y/o F wtih hx of HTN, afib on coumadin, dementia and CHF presents
   s/p unwitnessed fall at home ([**Location (un) 9290**]).  Was seen at [**Hospital 3434**]
   Hospital and had CT scan showing IPH and transferred here for further
   neuro eval.  Per the patient, she was washing her bathroom floor, when
   she felt a little unsteady and just fell.  Doesn't remember chest pain,
   shortness of breath, dizziness or any other precipitating factors.
   After talking with staff at her residence, she apparently was found in
   the bathroom bleeding this morning.  She had not pressed her life
   button.  It was unclear what time she had fallen or for how long she
   was down.  She is demented at baseline and has been getting worse over
   the last year, having increasing angry spells.  She is unsteady and
   supposed to use a walker, but she does not use it in her apartment.
   She has not had any signs of infection or change in her health
   recently.
   Fall(s)
   Assessment: Physical exam reveals a left orbital fracture with palpable step‑off and crepitus.
   Pt admitted S/P fall she is demented alert and oriented x1 @ baseline.
   Has bruise on her lt eye, No pain anywhere in her body, Had done rt eye
   cataract in the past, Lt eye pupil 3mm sluggish. Able move all four
   extremities. Follows commands, pleasant  and very cooperative w/ care.
   Action:
   Neuro assessment. Received 1 unit FFP in ED and one unit FFP upon
   arrival to ICU. PTT done INR 1.4. coumadin on hold. Neuro following.
   Response:
   Plan:
   Cont  to monitor mental status, C/O to floor.

value.text: No fractures.
Assessment: Physical exam reveals a left orbital fracture with palpable step‑off and crepitus.

data.doc_1:
24F s/p high speed MVC, engine found 25 feet from car, top sheared off,
   no prolonged extrication, unrestrained, +LOC, alternated between
   combativeness and somnolence, intubated in ED bay, sustained B/L hip
   dislocations/posterior wall fractures, R knee lac with tendon exposed.
   ETOH level on admission was 257.
   Injuries:
   - B/L hip dislocations with posterior wall fractures
   - R knee lac with exposed patellar tendon s/p washout
   - Left [**2-18**] rib fractures, L PTX (chest tube placed by trauma surgery)
   with underlying small pulmonary contusion
   Trauma, s/p MVC
   Assessment:
   Pt intubated and sedated at beginning of shift. Pt alert and following
   commands. C spine collar in place. CPAP vent weaned to minimal
   settings. Pt extubated without incident. Patient remained stable post-extubation. Pt speech clear, cooperative
   with exam to clear C spine. CIWA initiated [**1-16**] ETOH at time of
   admission. Pt tearful, mood labile, reports +anxiety at times. CIWA
   [**3-24**] this shift. HR 80-100s, SR, BP 120-100s/80s. +pp, +csm, +PBs
   applied. LS diminished at B/L bases, denies SOB, DOE, cough. Left chest
   tube to suction with minimal serosang output. Abd soft nontender
   nondistended, +BS, tolerating sips of clears, c/o intermittent nausea,
   no emesis. Foley in place, draining borderline u/o at start of shift.
   Exam by ortho PA this am, B/L knee immobilizers and hip abduction
   pillow applied to help prevent hip dislocation after reduction.
   Action:
   Collar removed. Pt rec
d 1 liter LR bolus at start of shift. Rec
   banana bag and KPhos replete. Repeat HCT sent this evening Pt given IS
   and instructed on use. Weaned to RA. Social work and pysch consult done
   today. Reassurance and emotional support provided. Ativan given for
   CIWA >11.
   Response:
   Pt BP and HR stable. Urine output improved after bolus. HCT stable. No
   s/s active bleeding. Pt able to maintain O2 sat > 92%. Pt mood
   improving over course of shift, declined additional anti-anxiety
   medication. Pt refused social work, agreed to speak with pysch MDs.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor VS, I&O and lab values. Monitor CIWA. Monitor CV
   and s/s bleeding. Monitor RESP and encourage aggressive pulmonary
   hygiene. Monitor MS and maintain immobilization until OR tomorrow with
   Ortho. Continue to monitor coping and f/u with social work and pysch.
   Impaired Skin Integrity
   Assessment:
   Anterior head laceration with staples OTA, no redness or active
   bleeding. Left chest tube dsg intact. Right knee dsg with serosang
   drainage, removed at start of shift. Right ankle abrasion red/pink, no
   drainage. Pt coccyx area +blanchable redness.
   Action:
   Wet to dry gauze and tegaderm dsg applied to right knee. Bacitracin
   ointment to right ankle abrasion. Pt remains on bedrest, turning side
   to side q2h and prn.
   Response:
   Right knee dsg remains intact. Right ankle abrasion improving.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor all sites. Repositioning and turning to maintain
   skin integrity and prevent breakdown
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
   Assessment:
   After extubation, pt reports +sharp constant pain in left side/chest.
   Denies pain in hips.
   Action:
   Pt rec
d 1mg iv Dilaudid with limited relief. MD aware. Dosage
   increased. Lidocaine patch applied to left side/back by chest tube. Pt
   assisted with repositioning for comfort.
   Response:
   Pt rec
d 2mg iv Dilaudid with improved comfort, resting upon
   reassessment.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor comfort and pain management. Assist with
   repositioning for comfort. Monitor coping and provide emotional
   support.

MVC car vs pole. driving at reportedly 4mph, hit pothole and slid into
   a pole. Pt was transferred from [**Hospital 1711**] hospital to [**Hospital1 5**]. CT abd at
   [**Hospital1 1711**] showed grade 4 splenic lac, left rib fx [**6-4**], pulmonary
   contusions. HCT stable at 38.
   Trauma, s/p MVC
   Assessment:Imaging of the chest shows no pulmonary contusions or other acute lung injury.
   Pt is alert, oriented, anxious.  He c/o pain rated [**2144-2-4**] near right
   and left side of ribs mainly with coughing and deep breathing.  Pt able
   to express when he needs pain medication.
   Action:
   Pt given .5mg dilaudid IVP for pain, emotional support, reminders about
   importance of coughing and deep breathing.  IS taught and practiced.
   Response:
   Pain well controlled with dilaudid, pt rested comfortably for most of
   the night.
   Plan:
   Change dilaudid IVP to PO meds for pain control.  Transfer pt to floor.
   Encourage coughing and deep breathing, practice IS frequently.
   Continue to support pt and family.  Discontinue foley in the AM.
   Anxiety
   Assessment:
   Pt has baseline ADHD and bipolar disorder.  He takes lithium [**Hospital1 **],
   seroquel qday, and adderol regularly.  Pt is pleasant and cooperative
   but occasionally seen anxious, nervous, and perseverating over money in
   relation to this hospital stay.  Pt expresses that he does not want to
   be hospitalized because the [**Doctor First Name **] will be too expensive and he will
   forever be in debt as a result which will in turn prevent him from
   going to college because he wont be able to afford it.  He is concerned
   about the price of CT scans and using electricity because of the cost.
   He is worried about the copays and the status of his health insurance
   (pt states that he was a [**Hospital1 **] Health plan member but has been
   expecting information from Mass Health because he intends to switch).
   Pt would rather rest at home and get better than sit in the hospital-he
   does not seem to understand the severity of his injuries despite the
   pain he feels.
   Action:
   Emotional support provided to pt constantly throughout the night,
   restful environment provided so that pt could stay on a regular sleep
   cycle while in the hospital.  Lithium, seroquel and other standing meds
   given, pain well controlled with dilaudid IVP.  Ativan IVP given PRN
   per HO for anxiety.
   Response:
   Pain well controlled, pt intermittently calm/perseverating on the cost
   of this hospital stay.  Pt slept well overnight after ativan given-
   tolerated ativan dose (.5mg IVP) well.
   Plan:
   SW consult recommended; consider psych consult?  Continue to support pt
   and family.  Involve the pt
s parents with money/price of hospital
   stay/college discussion to help ease pt
s concern and make his health a
   priority?  Have someone from finances come to talk with pt and family
   regarding the cost of this hospital stay.

Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)
   Assessment:
   82 y/o female POD #0 s/p CABG x 3. Out on propofol only. IVP morphine
   for perceived pain. Labile hemodynamics. CI < 2. Hypothermic. A-paced
   (underlying SR 60s-70s) for hemodynamic support. LS clear. 2
   mediastinal / 1L pleural CT, moderate amounts sanguineous hourly
   drainage. Abd soft obese. Absent bowel sounds. OGT bilious drainage.
   Foley in situ, patent, light yellow urine. Glucose > 120. Family at
   bedside post op, updated on POC. Supportive.
   Action:
   Added epi gtt at 0.02 mcg/kg/min.
   4L LR for volume resuscitation. Rec
d order for albumin.
   Repeat post op hct drawn.
   PEEP adjusted to assist with hemodynamics. CXR done x 2 post op shows L
   sided collapse [**Name8 (MD) 24**] NP [**Last Name (un) 9816**]. ? bronch prior to extubation.
   1 amp bicarb given to correct metabolic acidosis.
   Bair hugger and warm blankets to increase temp.
   Insulin gtt started.
   Response:
   Hct unchanged despite fluid resuscitation.
   Continues on epi gtt. CI up to 2.
   PEEP down to 5.
   Normothermic. Reversals not yet given.
   Titrating insulin gtt per protocol.
   Plan:
   Optimize hemodynamics.
   Reverse and lighten sedation. Neuro check.
   Wean vent as tolerated to extubation.
   Glucose control.
   Pain management.
   Post op education and support.

TITLE: CARDIOLOGY FELLOW CCU ADMISSION NOTE
   Please see housestaff H&P for full details.
   Briefly, this is an 89 year old woman with DM, HTN, and dyslipidemia
   who became acutely short of breath after eating Chinese food.  She
   later developed chest discomfort with associated nausea.   She
   presented to the emergency room where she was tachycardic to 120s,
   hypertensive to the 200s systolic and tachypneic with a respiratory
   rate in the 30s.  She was placed on bipap and a nitroglycerine gtt with
   significant improvement in her breathing.  Cardiac biomarkers were
   positive and EKG showed STE in avR and V1, STD in I, II, avL, V4-V6.
   PE: T97.6          P89                  BP 131/66
   RR20                94% 5L NC
   NAD, speaking in full sentences
   Bilateral crackles to [**12-11**] way up
   JVP 9, RRR, no murmurs

   LE warm, no edema
   Neuro
 decreased short term recall
   LABS:
   CK 954 -> 1133                         K 4.6                Co2
   16              BUN     41         Creatinine 1.9
   CKMB 150 -> 154
   Tn 2.56 -> 6.65                          WBC 13.2         HCT
   39.6           Plt 267
   TTE [**2141-2-9**]: The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild symmetric
   left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is
   normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction
   with septal hypokinesis. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right
   ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic
   root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets
   are mildly thickened (?#). There is no aortic valve stenosis. Mild (1+)
   aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly
   thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral
   regurgitation is seen. Tricuspid regurgitation is present but cannot be
   quantified. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There
   is no pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Regional LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD.
   A/P: 89 year old woman with CHF symptoms likely secondary to a primary
   ischemic event.  Given her initial respiratory distress, medical
   optimization was preferred to immediate cardiac catheterization.  After
   a lengthy discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 7045**], the patient was initially DNR/DNI;
   she later determined that she wishes to be full code and at this time
   does not wish to pursue cardiac catheterization.
   -          continue heparin gtt, nitroglycerine gtt

   and hypotension.
   .
   # Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea: Presentation c/w viral gastroenteritis. Low
   suspicion for bacterial infection or C. Diff. Pt has possible norovirus
   or rotavirus due to his wife with similar sx, and his quick onset and
   improvement of symptoms. This infection is likely causing the elevated
   lactate and SIRS sx.
   - IV rehydration as needed
   - start clear diet, ADAT
   - bismuth & zofran PRN
   - if diarrhea returns, would consider checking stool studies
   - f/u on blood cx from ER
   .
   # Hypotension/tachycardia: Likely [**3-5**] massive fluid losses. BP improved
   with aggressive IV rehydration. this is all likely secondary to his
   infection and hypovolemic state. Reportedly has low BP at baseline,
   which is consistent with lack of tachycardia with hypotension.
   - IVF as needed
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: likely secondary to dehydration. Cr
   improved to baseline.
   - trend Cr and BUN
   - D/c foley
   .
   # COPD hx: stable
   - will continue home inhaler
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: stable
   - will continue home meds

   # Hyperlipidemia: stable
   - continue home statin

57yo male s/p c/o dizziness, confusion, unsteady gait, vertigo, anxiety
   on [**3-18**]. EVD placed in ED for concern of malfunction of existing VP
   shunt. Head CT showed enlarged large lateral ventricle.  Pt has
   cysticercosis s/p resection of 4th ventricle cyst and hydrocephalus.
   Hydrocephalus/VP malfunction/infection:
   Assessment:
   Q1hr neuro checks continue: neuro exam unchanged, slightly complicated
   by language barrier. Pupils are 3mm/3mm, briskly reactive, pt unable to
   follow eyes upward (possibly d/t elevated pressure per neurosurgery
   team).  Tongue midline, smile symmetrical, follows all commands,
   verbally expresses needs (speech clear but sometimes difficult to
   understand d/t pt often speaks [**Location 2951**]).  Pt has full strength in
   all extremities, occasionally attempting to get out of bed with a
   purpose (bathroom).  Pt is alert and oriented x1-2: consistently knows
   self, able to identify that he is in the hospital, rarely knows the
   month/year, able to identify family member
s names, his birthday, etc.
   Pt denying pain throughout the shift. Keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
   Pt currently on IV antibiotics for suspected infection (WBC rising,
   cultures pending): acyclovir, vancomycin, ceftazidime.  ICP 4-12, CPP
   >65, drainage from EVD is clear (rarely blood tinged) 1-20cc/hr.
   Action:
   Q1hr neuro exams continued throughout the shift.  EEG done at 14:00 in
   room.  Pt supported emotionally, continuously reminded to stay in bed
   and to be cautious of EVD.
   Response:
   Pt restful in between neuro exams/repositioning. Pt does not attempt to
   pull at EVD, attempted to get out of bed more this AM, seems to
   understand rationale to stay in bed for safety.
   Plan:
   Continue Q1hr neuro exam v. change to Q2hrs? Transfer to SDU? MRI (MRI
   checklist completed in chart)?advance diet as tolerated. Bowel meds
   needed. Cycling troponins- last set due at 17:00. Continue to monitor
   rising creatinine, WBC and temp.

 moderate atherosclerotic calcification of the aortic arch and descending
 aorta.  There is moderate-to-severe three-vessel coronary artery
 calcification.

 Bilateral areas of fibrosis, scarring, and architectural distortion related to

 mass.  Central airways are patent to the subsegmental level, but again show
 some narrowing, and distortion, likely related to underlying fibrotic change.

 There is slightly increased airspace opacity at the left hilum, which could
 represent areas of atelectasis, or possibly early infection.  [**Hospital1 **]-apical
 pleural thickening is slightly increased since previous exam, particularly at
 the right lung apex.

 adrenal myelolipoma, and pancreatic cystic lesions are not visualized on this
